discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Administrator Asembly

Selected Answer: A
A is the right one

A is correct

From ICM 8-17
To integrate NSX-T Data Center with vRealize Automation, create a cloud account:
1 Log in to the vRealize Automation console as Cloud Assembly Administrator.
2 Navigate to Infrastructure > Connections > Cloud Accounts.
3 Click ADD CLOUD ACCOUNT > NSX-T.
4 Select NSX Mode.
5 Associate the vCenter Server instances.

comments.content:
This is correct. We can eliminate the other answers: 

A. Cloud Assembly Administrator - Yes
B. Cloud Assembly User - User, not admin... no way users should be adding NSX-T resources
C. Orchestrator Administrator - This has nothing to do with Orchestrator
D. NSX-T Data Center Enterprise Administrator - They're asking for the VRA side, not the NSX-T side

A is the only answer that makes sense

discussion.content: A is correct answer as question asks what "user role" is required to add cloud accounts, not asking for actual NSX-T credentials. https://docs.vmware.com/en/vRealize-Automation/8.1/Using-and-Managing-Cloud-Assembly/GUID-5A4C11E3-C7E6-4FBB-BFB3-F85C2FA28D6D.html#GUID-5A4C11E3-C7E6-4FBB-BFB3-F85C2FA28D6D

questions.question_text:
As part of a greenfield deployment, an administrator needs to set up an NSX-T Data Center cloud account.
Which user role is required to create an NSX-T Data Center cloud account in vRealize Automation? (Choose the best answer.)

The Quickstart wizard executes multiple actions when submitted.
What is one of the actions that is always executed by the Quickstart wizard? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content: Remember, 'vCenter Server Quickstart' & 'Guided Setup' in vRA Assembly are the same. The former option goes away it is run once, the later is always available in the upper right corner of the GUI. Both have the same goal of building out all the components to eventually deploy a machine to validate end-to-end. For vRA 8.3, the answer is C.

Ans is C 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/vRealize-Automation/8.4/Getting-Started-Cloud-Assembly/GUID-91597976-E472-493B-8017-2D37DC8DC0E5.html

comments.content: Answer is B and E, i gave the exam yesterday.

discussion.content:
Guys, please help me with this one:

An architect is completing the physical design for a vRealize Operation (vROps) solution for a
customer.
The customer has only provided the following information for their existing environment:
500 Virtual Machines
2 VMware vCenter Servers
10 VMware vSphere Horsts
20 Datastores
Live data should be stored within the vROps solution for 6 months
The RTO for all existing management components is 4 hours
The RTO for all existing management components is 1 hour
Which two assumptions could the architect make when sizing the vROps cluster? (Choose two.)

A. The vROps cluster will be configured as High Availability.
B. The RTO of the vROps solution will be 4 hours.
C. The resource profile of a virtual machine will be, on average, 1 vCPU and 2 GB RAM.
D. The minimum data retention within vRealize Operations Cluster will be 12 months.
E. The RPO of the vROps solution will be 1 hour.
C is the correct answer. A, B & D is not even mentioned when you run the quick start wizard.
https://blogs.vmware.com/management/files/2019/10/Screen-Shot-2019-10-16-at-4.37.51-PM-1-768x454.png It is C (the last step in Quick Start wizard)
I believe it's C: 'If you run the Quickstart wizard more than once, you will have cloud templates that are created for each wizard configuration.'

comments.content: As your own link shows, correct answer is C

discussion.content:
A is correct
https://docs.vmware.com/en/vRealize-Automation/8.3/Getting-Started-Cloud-Assembly/GUID-7D54B742-CC49-42E4-B138-0B121B334733.html

choices.D: Execute subscriptions for an event topic
choices.C: Request a deployment from a machine catalog item

discussion.content:
Think this should be B as you would configure the IP range there to use the TAG correctly.
https://virtualrove.com/2020/07/23/vmware-vrealize-automation-8-1-part4-network-profiles/

comments.content:
The more I think about this the more I agree that B is correct, for two reasons:

1. Network Profiles are where we determine IP allocation methodology, something that occurs in this error. Tags won't fix that problem.
2. We can assign tags in the Network Profile.

discussion.content:
I think the answer is B

In the reasons presented by the statement said: Network Profile was skipped because cannot allocate a network with static IP address range for the profile. We can guess here that the Constraint Tag configured in the Cloud Template (blueprint) is OK as Aria Automation matches it with the Network Profile during deployment. However, the Network profile does not have any Networks with IP Ranges configured. If the problem was Tag the error would be different.

Selected Answer: C
I vote for C - They key here is where would you "Start" to troubleshoot. Yes the network profile needs to be checked and availability of IPs on the subnet etc etc. But the tag logic needs to be validated first to determine what networks are or are not available due to tag constraints

Selected Answer: B
In the network profile you include the IP ranges that will be used in the deployment of a virtual machine cloud template, therefore the correct answer is B
i agree with C, the key is cloud template deployment, related to the message error to start tshoot we must know what is the tag vlan we put

I think this should be C. If you look at the Error Log. It states, "unable to find a valid subnet for network 'Network_External' of type 'EXISTING' with constraints '[dc:metro, tier:1' 
Because this specifically brings up constraints, it has to be tag related first.

I would go with B, but this seems like a bad question.

It seems like the kind of problem where either the network profile is right and the tags are wrong, in which case we pick C. 

However, it's also possible the tags are correct and the network profile is wrong, so we should pick B.

questions.question_text:
An administrator is configuring vRealize Automation to generate a unique machine naming convention for the deployed resources.
The machine name should meet the following criteria:
XXX-YYY-ZZZ-##
✑ XXX `" Cloud Zone
✑ YYY `" Server Function
✑ YYY `" Application
✑ ## `" 2-digit running number
Which component should the administrator use to configure this policy? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is the only valid option. Naming convention can either be set at the org (newer feature) or at the project levle.

Indeed C is correct

When you go to projects and provisioning tab, there is the option to Custom Naming section
C is Correct
vRealize Orchestrator is correct

Answer is C

For Aria Automation Cloud (this is the SaaS version) if we want to use extensibility functions provided by vRO, we need to deploy the VMware Aria Automation extensibility proxy on-premise because this is not included in the cloud services.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Aria-Automation/SaaS/Using-Automation-Assembler/GUID-3F363A84-4F4F-4B77-B38F-547C85F84B7C.html

Selected Answer: C
vRO is also available embedded, but the external vRO is the tried and true historical (scalable) way to deploy vRO.

Answer is C correct 
Once complete, the console shows the services and options which are available. You can add users and configure roles by selecting Identity & Access Management from the menu bar. If you’re using Active Directory, remember you’ll need to add those details in vIDM or LCM through Locker before users and groups will appear in vRA 8.

In addition to the aforementioned services, vRealize Orchestrator (vRO) is accessible from the Console, as well as the vRA Migration Assessment. vRO no longer uses a java client. Instead you can access the embedded vRO via the new HTML 5 UI through this console. An external vRO appliance option is available too
